Fields.DialogueText: A word, Verdun?
Oui, Capitaine, but it will have to be quick. I cannot keep the sailors running forever... much as I would like to.
That's actually what I wanted to discuss. Is all this really necessary?
It is a Belle's responsibility to keep her crew in fighting shape, for their sake and her own.

Fields.MenuText: And how long have they been running?
They won't be in fighting shape if you kill them all first.
It's the captain's responsibility to make sure his Belle doesn't run his crew ragged between engagements.

Fields.DialogueText: I do not wear a watch, but I suspect it has not been long enough. Instinct tells me more than a timepiece ever could.
Ne t'inquiète pas. I have already ordered them not to die.
It is the crew's responsibility to exceed the expectations of their capitaine. Checks and balances, as Montesquieu said.
What are you hoping to accomplish?
Call it an inoculation. The Morganas will be hard-pressed to strike fear into those who have supped the sacrament of death.
It's good that you keep close to the crew, but try to keep the infirmary clear.
No promises, Capitaine, they... Marin! Genoux plus élevés!
What if they pass your tests?
Then they get to train the others when I'm called away.
How does that go?
There are two types of people, Capitaine. Those who want the pain to stop and those who want a turn at it. Nothing sorts the two out like a bit of power.
And which one are you?
Any reasonable person is the former. Against the enemy, one must dabble in the latter. These Morganas, par exemple.
@BATTLE
L'ennemi est proche - Capitaine sur le pont!
@BATTLE
Patrol est comme d'habitude. Les Morganas...
What are you writing?
Ah, salut, Capitaine. I am recording the day's events in my log.
I usually never see you writing.
Oui. I try to write on my own, in the hour before I sleep. Easier to concentrate.
I wasn't entirely sure you needed to sleep.
Humans do not need to sleep on beds, and yet you prefer it. Comfort is not high on my list of priorities, but I find that it is important to be well rested for battle.

Fields.MenuText: So what brings you out here to the mess hall?
Easier said than done. You never know when a Morgana will find you.
As well rested as one can be on a destroyer.

Fields.DialogueText: Some nights it is the only place I can work.
You must not be afraid, Capitaine. The Morganas will certainly not be.
Better a rest aboard me than at the bottom of the ocean.
Tu vois, the night after a battle, I cannot write in my quarters. It is difficult to concentrate.
Even warships need time to cool off, I guess.
We are all food for shells and guns. It is less the battle and more the temptation.
Temptation?
... My sewing. If I so much as touch a needle I will be at it until dawn, and then nothing will have been written.
Target practice and sewing... I can't think of two more different hobbies.
They are more similar than you know. Both require precision and careful consideration. You cannot retrieve a shell once fired or a whole piece of cloth once cut.
Or ink once put to paper.
Précisément. Or time once spent in idleness.
Is that my cue to leave you to it?
I am more than capable of writing and speaking. I would appreciate your company.
All ahead full, Verdun, they're flanking that passenger ship!
Iron are our lives, men! When these witches return to Hell, they will speak of you in whispers!
... That's something to think about.
This is war, Capitaine. Fear is a weapon like any other.
@BATTLE
I still sense some uninvited guests, Capitaine.
Yes, I was just about to tell you. That passenger ship the Morganas attacked was bound for New York. We saved who we could from the wreck.
To what end?
We're out here to protect civilian traffic. If refugees can't get safe passage to America, we escort or deliver who we can to Britain.
Je comprends, but I wonder if we would not serve Command better elsewhere. I am a destroyer - I would rather destroy.

Fields.MenuText: I can request deployments closer to the maelstroms, but it would be a long shot.
Orders are orders. Command is playing it close to the chest for now.
As long as we are defending the North Atlantic, we should protect the people crossing it.

Fields.DialogueText: Bien. We cannot shatter our enemy without bloodying our noses a little.
For all the good these escort missions do against the Morganas, Command may as well be playing Salvo.
They knew the risks when they embarked.
We'll only have the civilians aboard until we're in port again. Be nice to them until then.
The Morganas have declared war on humanity, Capitaine. You are all soldiers, and if it helps you to survive I will treat you as such.
Let me be a little clearer. You are not to include the civilians in your morning runs.
You don't think they need the exercise?
I don't think they need heart attacks. Not everyone can run five kilometers before dawn.
A war zone is a war zone... but you are my capitaine.
@BATTLE
Are you headed to the civilians' quarters?
Oui. There are matters I must discuss with one of the gentlemen.
Is anything wrong?
Look down and to your left. The answer is crudely painted on that bulkhead.

Fields.MenuText: What exactly is that a drawing of?
Is that... a picture of you? It's not bad.
One of the refugee kids is going to be a great artist one day.

Fields.DialogueText: Moi, I am forced to assume. Out of proper uniform, I might add.
Hmph. I have better trigger discipline than that... facsimilé.
Peut-être, but for now they are annoying.
Then those must be Morganas you're fighting.
It appeared after today's battle, Capitaine, and I recognize the Morganas in the picture. Someone's child has been somewhere they should not have been.
You don't know that. One of the sailors might have described the battle to the kids.
Aucune différence. I will not have civilians bringing the home front here. It does not mix with destruction's lurid reign.
They're just kids. War doesn't have to be all gloom and doom.
While I'm at it, I may as well clean up this travesty of art.
Wait! Verdun, behind you...
Qu'est-ce que c'est, Capitaine?
... And there she goes. I think you've upset the artist.
Merde...
To arms! L'ennemi est proche!
Isn't there somewhere else you should be?
If you have a better use for my time than honing my skills, by all means suggest it. Tire!
*BOOM*
I was hoping you had apologized to the little girl you traumatized.
Écoutez-vous. You throw that word around like a ruined drawing is an artillery bombardment. She does not know what trauma is.
She's six years old!
I am technically nine, with several battles to my name already. Tire!
*BOOM*

Fields.MenuText: Children are not destroyers, Verdun.
Don't give me that. You may have been built recently, but you have centuries of experience.
She made that drawing for you, you know.

Fields.DialogueText: Personne n'est parfait.
I carry the memory of millions of soldiers with me. She can handle one bad day.
There is a time and a place for fantasy, Capitaine, and it is not on the battlefield.
She watched her hero erase her drawing. You've never been a child, but that's heartbreaking to her.
There is her mistake. Fulfilling a purpose does not make one a hero.
Then what does?
Une question inutile. Heroes die. The quick stir of wonder does not last a whole war. If these civilians see strength in me, they should strive to find it in themselves.
Just consider it, will you?
You know I do not care for public relations.
I'm not asking you to look good for a camera. I'm asking you to be better for a kid.
Tire!
*BOOM*
Action stations, I suppose.
Oui. Et Capitaine?
Verdun?
Her name is Elise.
@BATTLE
To your stations! Ce n'est pas un exercice!
@BATTLE
"Fair was the morning, fair our tempers, and we had seen nothing fairer than that land..."
That's the Celtic Sea behind us. You can finally relax, Verdun — the refugees will be safe in port.
Pas assez. The further inland, the better.
I saw them off. That little girl seemed happier.
Elise.
Yes, Elise. She asked if you were still sad.
Alors. Do I seem sad?

Fields.MenuText: You certainly don't seem happy.
No, but I can see how a child would think so.
Is something on your mind?

Fields.DialogueText: Perhaps it is because we only ever seem to drive off these Morganas, rather than destroy them. Anyone would find it vexing.
The world is more complex than happiness and sadness. She will learn.
Rien d'important.
Well, she said she'd miss you. She appreciated what you did for her.
I haven't the slightest idea what you're talking about.
She wouldn't stop talking about that new coat she was wearing. I wonder who made it for her.
Who, indeed.
And in such vibrant gold and blue...
Charmant.
With the coat of arms of Verdun embroidered on the back.
... Ce n'est rien. I took something of hers. It was only right that I give something back.
I hadn't seen her smile so much since we rescued her. Thank you, Verdun.
Think nothing of it.
What if I choose to think that you're nicer than you let on?
Believe what you will, but please keep it to yourself. I am a soldier, not a seamstress.
Verdun, how are you...?
Ne bougez pas, Capitaine! Do not come between me and my quarry!
What are you talking about?
Capitaine, some vermin has had its way with my quarters! That... are we alone?

Fields.MenuText: As far as I'm aware.
You're the ship. You tell me.
The crew is sworn to secrecy in either case.

Fields.DialogueText: Merde... here will have to do.
C'est vrai. Let me see... non, we have nothing to fear.
Oaths are worthless unless backed by flesh. Even so, I must be forthcoming.
As I was saying, that evening dress I've spent the past two weeks on is ruined! Some filthy trench rat is responsible, and I will not rest until...
Whose cat is that?
Quel chat?
Behind you.
Excellent! I will feed it the little monster that has defiled my...
Is that... lace in its mouth?
Non... il ne peut pas être ...
One of the refugees must have left it behind. No, maybe it snuck on when we were in port? There's no collar...
A noose will suffice!
*ALARM*
Verdun, it'll have to wait!
It must be the toil of another day. A moment while I seal my quarters, Capitaine. I can skin this beast later!
@BATTLE
What are you doing down there?
Taisez-vous. That little demon will rue the day it destroyed my work. I have laid a foolproof trap.
You've propped up a box on a ruler with a rope tied to it. Over a dead fish.
Simple creatures call for simple traps.
How long have you had that set up?
Since I woke. A vile, sickly smell of rottenness... it will get hungry eventually.

Fields.MenuText: It'd better. Your bait is really fouling up the room.
What will you do with her if you catch her?
For heaven's sake, it's just a dress!

Fields.DialogueText: The trenches were worse. I will clean when my work is done.
Make a handbag of the beast and cook the rest for a stew.
There will be other dresses, just as there will be other cats!
Verdun...
Wait! Capitaine, she is close by. I can feel her!
Verdun, stop!
Je ne.... Merde!
Foolproof indeed.
Ugh. This uniform will take a whole evening to wash...
Well, the cat certainly likes it.
What...? Grr. If it were not cleaning my uniform I would gut it in an instant!
Save it for after the Morganas. I think it likes you, anyway. See, it's purring!
I'll give it something to purr at.
@BATTLE
That cat sure seems to enjoy your company. Peace in our time, eh?
Je ne l'encourage pas. She simply will not stop following me.
It's a her?
Peu importe. No matter where I go, she seeks me out.
Maybe she's hoping you'll take another fish to the chest.
I remember, and my heart grows cold.

Fields.MenuText: If you don't want it, I'll keep it. The ship could use a pet.
Whatever you do with it, don't kill it. They're supposed to be lucky.
Admit it. You were outsmarted by a cat.

Fields.DialogueText: The ship could use a dog. A big one.
We must deal with enough of the supernatural without creating our own. But I will defer to your judgment.
I do not deal in pride, Capitaine. Nevertheless, the cat and I have a score to settle.
Can I ask you to keep an eye on it, since it seems to hang around you?
I save cruelty for battle, Capitaine, but I make no promises about apathy.
That's a start.
It's hissing. Action stations, Capitaine.
It can sense Morganas?
Perhaps we have a use for it after all.
@BATTLE
Capitaine? Puis je entrer?
Of course, Verdun. Come in.
Merci. I cannot concentrate anywhere else.
Sewing?
Cat.

Fields.MenuText: Where is she now?
You haven't done anything with her, have you?
I thought they were supposed to sleep most of the day.

Fields.DialogueText: Where isn't she? Cats have the uncanny ability to appear where they please.
Not for lack of trying.
You may as well ask her.
What I do know is that she is not in my quarters, grâce à Dieu. That is a mistake I shall not repeat.
She followed you around, didn't she?
Have you ever tried to write with a cat rubbing its head against your hand?
That sounds frustrating, yet incredibly adorable.
I will take that as a no.
You're getting close to the end of that log. I can get you another notebook if you like.
Je l'apprécierais, Capitaine. This log has been... different.
The refugees, the cat... it's certainly been lively lately.
In all the wrong ways. Give me gunfire, smoke, a blurred confusion of yells and groans...
You can't possibly prefer that to the cat.
It is not a question of preference, Capitaine, but familiarity... and judging by the trajectory of those Morganas, we're about to familiarize ourselves with it again.
@BATTLE
La chatte and I have finally reached an understanding.
Should I be worried?
Certainement pas. Call it a bit of frontline inventiveness.
... Why are your legs bare? You're so serious about uniform...
Think on this, Capitaine. What is a cat's most vexing habit?

Fields.MenuText: Leaving toys around?
Scratching, probably.
You say vexing, I say charming.

Fields.DialogueText: Merely an exercise of its hunting instincts.
Exactement. And thus a solution.
You are not without vexations of your own.
I do not know much about cats, Capitaine, but I know that they need to scratch things to renew their claws. And you know I am invulnerable...
That's... resourceful.
It gives her something to do other than shred my fabric.
I haven't seen her in a while. Have you been feeding her as well?
There is no shortage of fish out at sea. She is, as they say, well-spiced and hearty.
And to think that not long ago you were trying to kill her.
She has proven agreeable. Now we shall see if she proves useful.
She's certainly good at detecting the Morganas. Hear that?
That'll be her at the door. Such a companionable animal. Bien joué, ma petite chasseresse!
@BATTLE
Our target today is Malice, Verdun.
So I am told. Comment très prévisible.
Predictable? That's not the word I'd use to describe the Morgana attacks.
Not the attacks, Capitaine. The names. Do you not see them for the diversion they are?
What kind of diversion?
Your human countries name ships to communicate pride in your history, to boast of strength to allies and rivals. Not to inspire fear.
The Morganas are a different story. They don't have a history that we know of.
C'est vrai. Their purpose, so far as we know, is to destroy you. To destroy us. But why broadcast it?

Fields.MenuText: Why don't you ask one?
Does it matter?
You're saying they have something to hide?

Fields.DialogueText: Maybe I will, right before I consign her to the abyss.
In the end, non. But it is something I wish the men would think more on.
I'm saying that there must be more to them than simple destruction.
After all, a name is not just a word, non? It is an identity. Surely the Morganas must call each other by different names than humans would call them.
So there's no reason to fear their names as we know them.
Or to dwell on the names they might hide. We do not have to fear one or the other when we fire, nor even the dread of barrage suddenly falling.
I suppose not.
Little Fleury certainly does not.
Who?
Fleury! I grew bored of calling our companion "la chatte."
And what's in her name?
A village that was captured sixteen times during the Battle of Verdun. Small, flighty, and unpredictable, but ultimately on the right side of things.
I'm glad you're getting along.
I am glad I have an alarm system I can pet.
@BATTLE
Pschtt! Go on, play with your toys!
At an impasse?
Non.
Fleury says otherwise.
She insists on sleeping on my notebook. I cannot turn incorporeal to circumvent her, because I cannot hold a pen in that form.
So move her.
Move her?
Oh, come on. She's a cat, you're a destroyer.
But she's asleep.
Never stopped you before. What's gotten into you?
If anything might rouse her now...
Whoa!
Fleury! Descends du Capitaine!
... Apologies, Capitaine.

Fields.MenuText: Verdun, get your cat off my head.
She really does value her sleep.
Accepted. I almost want to borrow her now.

Fields.DialogueText: Fleury, le capitaine n'est pas une chaise!
You see my dilemma now.
I would be happy to lend her to you while I write.
Looks like you've met your match.
Stand still while I solve this, Capitaine.
Stand still... Verdun, wait!
Fleury, viens par ici!
Well, at least we got her down.
... Oui.
And now she's hissing again. That'll be a Morgana. Verdun?
Capitaine?
You can get off me now.
... Bien sûr.
@BATTLE
La chatte est en détresse! Les ennemis sont proches!
@BATTLE
Here you go, Capitaine.
My complete Shakespeare! That was fast.
I did not finish it, Capitaine. I have come to exchange it for your Mahan.
The Influence of Sea Power on World History? That's... ambitious.
You know my reading speed, Capitaine.
I thought you wanted to read all of the plays.
I have decided against it for now.

Fields.MenuText: Can I ask why?
You stopped halfway through Henry V. I thought for sure you'd like that one.
A couple more days couldn't hurt.

Fields.DialogueText: It is more pertinent to my tour of duty.
I do. That is why I must cut it short.
A lot can happen in a couple of days.
If you say so.
Merci. The gold laurel of all victories is not awarded to the unfocused.
What's gotten into her?
Is it me, or is Fleury sleeping a lot more lately?
It is not you. She is playing at being a soldier.
What, is she joining the men in training?
Oui.
Heh. You sold that pretty well. You might have a future in acting.
What do you mean?
... You weren't joking, were you?
Rarely, if ever.
Verdun, she's just a cat!
Elle s'est portée volontaire. Fleury's outpacing the men already.

Fields.MenuText: How do you know she volunteered?
Well, talk to me when she learns to fire your main guns.
Should I be laughing or sighing?

Fields.DialogueText: Fleury took one look at our morning sprints and off she went. I admire her initiative.
Given her curiosity, I would not be surprised if she stumbled upon how.
A little of both, Capitaine.
That must be entertaining reading in your logs. You'll have to show me sometime.
Perhaps when we've dealt with this immediate threat. Do not worry about the men. I know they will fight ‘til Hell's last horror breaks them.
It's not the Morganas that worry me...
@BATTLE
Verdun, do you have a moment? I thought I'd take a look at the logs.
After the Destruction has been driven off. Allow my gunfire to speak for me.
Eloquent as always.
@BATTLE
You wanted to see this, Capitaine?
Thank you, Verdun.
I cannot fathom why. I simply recapitulate the events of our tour of duty.

Fields.MenuText: Why wouldn't I be interested in a Belle's perspective on war?
It's not just a recap, it's your recap.
I'll trade you mine.

Fields.DialogueText: I do not think you will find it as interesting as all that.
Just another soldier, Capitaine. You may as well ask one of the sailors.
I appreciate the offer, but it would be nothing you could not tell me in person.
"... the sea air reminds me of my home. Not merely the one I defend, but the one I inhabit to defend it." Verdun, this is beautiful!
I do not strive for beauty, Capitaine. I describe the world in a way that makes sense to me.
Have you considered poetry? You quote enough of it.
I have never dealt in human hopeful things.
Case in point. Even so, you read enough to know the power of words. People might really appreciate a war narrative from a destroyer's perspective.
Bof. Novelty at best.
You wouldn't write if it didn't do something for you.
It allows me to get my thoughts in order, Capitaine. Whether someone else perceives it as I do is none of my concern.
"There is no greater reward than victory, and its closest cousin is memory?"
J'ai dit ça. Let history be the judge of my memory.
What's on your mind?
War. Tire!
*BOOM*
Somehow, it's never just war.
C'est vrai. Sometimes I think about sewing.
As you do.
Tire!
*BOOM*
Have you been listening to the Morganas again?
We discussed this already. Dismay's slow, corroding stain has come and gone.
Verdun, I'm worried about you. You've been terse lately.
Have you met me? Tire!
*BOOM*
You're avoiding the question. You know, it's been a while since we last danced. Maybe we should take it easy when we get back to port.
You may do so. The Morganas will not.
Verdun, I...
Tire!
*BOOM*
Morganas inbound. Should Fleury really be out here right now?
I trained her to operate the clay pigeon thrower. No sense in monopolizing a sailor for my personal training.
That's considerate of you.
The word you are looking for is efficient. Aux armes.
@BATTLE
Has the mail delivery been delayed, Capitaine?
By a day or two. The weather doesn't agree with us right now.
I was under the impression that they delivered even in the midst of storms.
Natural storms, yes. But this one isn't moving.
Meaning it's Morgana in origin.
It appears to be.
Alors pourquoi attendons-nous? Let us find out what is at the storm's eye.

Fields.MenuText: We don't know. That's why we're waiting for them to come to us.
If I could get through to Command right now, believe me, I would.
Let's not get reckless. We're under orders to guard Nantes right now.

Fields.DialogueText: We cannot let the enemy dictate the terms of our engagement, Capitaine.
What I would do for a homing pigeon or twelve...
A ship in harbor is safe, but that is not what a ship is for.
Our hands are tied for now, Verdun.
Unable to strike our enemies at sea, unable to communicate with allies on land. Fruitless in all but fame.
I wish there were something more I could do.
Moi aussi. I suppose I will return to my letters.
Letters?
Logs.
You definitely said letters. Letters to whom?
Never you mind about that. I think I hear Fleury now.
That cat's starting to rub off on you.
@BATTLE
Nasty out here, isn't it?
I believe the British refer to situations like this as "a bit sticky."
Doesn't that mean we're in danger? I haven't heard a sound out of Fleury.
That is because she is terrified. Look there.
That is... a fair few Morganas.
We have found the source of this storm. Capitaine, our course of action is obvious.

Fields.MenuText: Surprise isn't on our side. We need to dig in and draw them out.
Request aid from nearby patrols. We'll take them here and now.
This is bad. We'd be fighting the Morganas entirely on their terms. We should notify Command first and keep our distance in the meantime.

Fields.DialogueText: We cannot dig a trench at sea, Capitaine, but we may certainly try.
There is too much interference and our allies are too far for flares. This is our problem.
Non, we would leave too much to chance. Who knows whether this storm will continue to grow?
You realize that this is an insane idea.
Oui. War will not wait to make sense. We have found ourselves in the right place at the right time.
Don't you mean the wrong place?
That depends on how well we perform in battle. Do not worry, Capitaine. Ours will be a story of ancient glory, sweetly told.
Hopefully by us.
On ne peut qu'espérer.
Action stations, then. And Verdun?
Capitaine?
Good luck.
Luck is what we make of adversity. I will save some for you.
@BATTLE
Toutes les mains aux stations de combat! Vite!
@BATTLE
Oh, hello, Verdun! Do you have a moment?
Capitaine, are you holding what I think you're holding?
Yes, the post arrived while you and the crew were shooting. First mail ship since the storm cleared...
Give that to me at once!
What's the matter?
Rien n'est la matière. Only that this letter need not concern you.
What are you talking about? It's from someone in Cork named...
Pardonnez-moi!
Verdun!
Ahem... Je m'excuse, Capitaine. It is a matter of strict operational security between Command and myself.

Fields.MenuText: Via civilian post from Cork.
If you don't want to share it with me, I won't force you.
Whatever it is, you're certainly treating it as such. Ouch...

Fields.DialogueText: We Belles operate through diverse and inscrutable channels.
Nor could you if you tried.
Est-ce que tu vas bien? I forget that humans are more delicate than I am...
Never mind. Just help me up, I think I'm all right.
Êtes-vous sûr? I can have you patched up and quick to be gone.
Verdun, it was just a shove. I'll be fine.
D'accord. Please excuse me, I must answer this at once.
Now where's she off to?
... And who the hell is "Elise?"
Nous sommes presque à portée de tir, Capitaine!
@BATTLE
What's the fire for?
I felt confined below decks. Warmth was the answer.
You'd think someone who knows the trenches of the Western Front wouldn't have that problem.
Even I have my preferences.
What are you burning, anyway?
Ce ne sont que des ordures. Trash.
Are those... Verdun, we need water at once!
Au contraire. All is right in the best possible of worlds.
Those are your logs in there!
Old logs. I have committed them to memory.

Fields.MenuText: But your insights... your perspective... you're just throwing it away.
Do you do this with all of your writing?
How in the world do you manage that?

Fields.DialogueText: They are mine to do with as I please, not the world's to slot into place like a puzzle piece.
Every scrap.
My memory encompasses millions of French dead. What are a few more corpses to me?
Look here. It is the letter I seized.
Elise Kramer, Cork... I know that name.
You may know her art better.
That little girl from before? You're burning her letter?
I have responded to it already.
What do you talk about?
Silly things. Children's games, school, questions about the world. It is strange... her heart was shaken with tears aboard me, and yet she sees such beauty in this world.
Children are like that.
Donc, ils sont. What good fortune that I never was one.
Another letter for you, Verdun.
Merci. Elise will have her response within the week.
You don't tell her... everything that goes on, do you?
As a matter of security, non. But she knows a little about the soldier's life.
Sewing and all?
If soldiers did not know how to patch up their uniforms, the trenches would be full of freezing, filthy, naked men. One of those has an easy solution.

Fields.MenuText: There's more to it than that.
Most soldiers don't make evening gowns.
What does Elise think about that?

Fields.DialogueText: Little of consequence.
Most soldiers only have their own experience to deal with.
She says, and I quote, that I am "silly." I do not envy her naivete.
So why do you talk to her?
Perhaps for the same reason I burn my logs, Capitaine.
You never did clear that up.
Think of little Fleury, Capitaine. Think of how she must scratch at things to prepare the way for new claws. So it is with my work. It does not do to dwell on things.
But you memorize everything.
I recognize my work as a part of my experience and move on from it. So should we all.
Yet you've been writing back and forth for... how long, now?
Weeks. I will get over my curiosity soon.
Don't. Curiosity is how you learn.
Curiosity is a shackle! I cannot dull myself to the hum of passing shells, Capitaine. Elise too will be scratched away one day.
You'd be surprised how hard it is to forget something once you grow fond of it.
Surprised by a shell to my unsuspecting face.
Surprised by how hard you'll fight to protect it.
Here is a Morgana to prove half your point, at least.
@BATTLE
Here.
Qu'est-ce que c'est?
My Shakespeare. You left off at Henry V, I think.
You have chosen quite a time to hand this to me, Capitaine, with the Sabotage bearing down on us.
Apparently I can only get through to you in the middle of a battle. Any time else would be a distraction.
C'est hilarant.
@BATTLE
Make it quick, Capitaine, or Fleury will grow impatient. Tire!
*BOOM*
Verdun, I'm worried about you.
Ne soyez pas, Capitaine.
It's like you've completely about-faced. Like you're not the same person who wanted to be remembered. An inspiration.
When do we stop being the same person? When does a cat scratch its way to a new set of claws? What remains of your past self after even a week's battles?
Everything. You're not just a warship, you know.
Have I reason to be otherwise? Tire!
*BOOM*
Fleury thinks so. Elise thinks so. I'm willing to bet you do too.
Merde. I do not allow myself to be distracted.
We all do! It's what keeps us sane, Verdun. We dance and we sew and we read and we take some beauty from the horror we face. You yourself told me that.
Cat scratches! I dally with my hobbies, my acquaintances, but I do not let them slow me down.
You're the best soldier I've ever seen because of those pieces of you, not in spite of them. What are you afraid of?
You!
What?
I found you in a holy place apart, Capitaine! Fearless in battle, yet unafraid to let your guard down out of it! War is your occupation, but it is not your purpose as it is mine!
I cannot afford to let my guard down as you do, Capitaine, no matter how I may dabble. I must leave behind what I cannot take into battle, and I cannot take sewing, cannot take love—
Take what?
... Excusez-moi!
Welcome back.
Merci.
Fleury's missed you.
She was welcome to find me.
Not when you don't want to be found.
How do you do it, Capitaine?
Do what?
Set aside your concerns? Your purpose? Don't you know there's a war on?

Fields.MenuText: Of course I do. That's why I have to set it aside every once in a while. But it doesn't stop being there.
We wouldn't be here if there weren't.
I don't have a purpose, Verdun, any more than you do. It's yours to decide.

Fields.DialogueText: If we battle an implacable enemy, we must be equally implacable.
Précisément! That does not sound like a purpose to you?
I did not decide to be a destroyer.
Look at it this way. What does Fleury mean to you?
... She is calm. Oblivious, même. Somehow peaceful in the midst of war.
What does Elise mean to you?
She has so much still to learn... and somehow does not lose her faith in a good and just world.
Does this make you any less able to fight the Morganas?
... Then there is you, Capitaine.
Me?
Vous. Tu. You see the potential in things beyond their immediate utility. Even though you may lose them in an instant. That does not terrify you? Victory is the one thing you cannot lose!
Hope is stronger than fear. You know this, no matter what you tell yourself.
Capitaine...
... What was that?
Un bisou. Consider it a token of hope for the battle ahead. With heavy hearts we'll tread the shadows, but we will not do so alone.
@BATTLE
You're hitting the poetry hard these days.
C'est vrai. Making up for lost time.
Have you considered writing any of your own?
I skipped sewing last night to do just that.
How is that coming?
If you had ever wondered how many glasses of wine it takes for the Muse to speak to you, the answer is two.

Fields.MenuText: I'd love to read it someday. War poetry is brutal stuff. Right in your wheelhouse.
How did you come to that conclusion?
Hitting the ground running, I see.

Fields.DialogueText: Brutality must be felt to be appreciated. It is amazing what words can do.
Plenty of experimentation. Do not worry, Belles can take it.
There is no point in running if you are not outrunning something.
So where does that lead you in this book?
Perspective, je pense.
Perspective?
"I could not love thee (Dear) so much / Lov'd I not Honour more." Richard Lovelace. A soldier of fortune, incidemment.
Dark, isn't it?
I prefer "realistic." I thought the small things distracted from my purpose.
Yet somehow, the drive to fight, the thought of losing those things in an instant... kept bringing them back.
Fleury. Elise.
You.
Me.
We are soldiers, you and I. That is what we do. But what are we, Capitaine?
That's for us to decide.
Bien joué, Fleury, ma douce. And yes, Capitaine, that is for us to decide. I have made a decision now.
Enlighten me.
When the time is right, I will.
